title: Canadian citizen H1B layoff
question: I'm Canadian citizen on H1B. I was laid off 1 month ago. Now the new employer is in the process of transfering my H1B. I was told it will take 3-4 weeks to get it transferred.
answers:
I will agree with the previous attorney. Also did your employer affirmatively revoke the H1B? If no, then next step is to know if you received a receipt from the new transfer. If yes, under AC 21, you should be able to start working for the new company. Often if approved, the USCIS might refer the case to a consular processing. I will recommend two things:

1. Go for premium processing;
2. Use a good lawyer on the case.

Good Luck

You can, but at arguably significant risk. Such a delayed filing for extension of status is unwise. If you apply for an extension after lay off, then the new I-94 is often denied. In fact, it is unclear if your new employer will qualify to petition you for an H1-b. A new memo has created unexpected problems for employers and the attorneys that represent them.

Most attorneys recommend that the H1-b visa holder leave the U.S. and process the new H1-b outside the U.S. The moment that the extension is denied, you can be deemed out of status. As a result, H1-b visa processing outside the U.S. can be delayed causing more frustration.

Due to the Neufeld memo, on what constitutes a valid employer-petition, many H1-b visas are being re-examined and denied for reasons that do not seem to be based upon the law and related H1-b regulations. An appeal can take years to resolve.

If your employer has not retained an attorney, then I recommend that you make an appointment or teleconference with an experienced immigration attorney. Perhaps, there is hope, but more questions must be answered, which can take more time and effort.

The above is general information and does not create an attorney client relationship.
